Award.AwardTitle: Manufacturing of Responsive and Functional Nanoporous Metal/polymer Heterostructures using Strain Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to investigate both the manufacturing process and properties of polymer-nanoporous metal bilayers. Nanoporous (NP) metals are a unique class of materials that are characterized by very high surface-to-volume ratios and possess such desirable properties of metals as high electrical conductivity and strength. The abundance of free surfaces is thought to give rise to many of the unusual properties of NP metals, including the ability to actuate in response to various external stimuli. These materials have shown great promise in many applications, including small-scale sensors and actuators. In this work, polymer-NP metal bilayers will be manufactured through nano-scale self-assembly processes with the ultimate goal of obtaining compliant, responsive, and functional three dimensional heterostructures. Heterostructures are structures made of different materials to obtain new properties. Specifically, this work will explore how mismatched strains affect the self-assembly of NP metals on polymer substrates, as well as the overall morphology of the structure. The response and fatigue behavior of the self-assembled heterostructures under different stimuli will be examined.

The proposed research can lead to fundamental advances in understanding of the role of interfacial mismatching of strains and how they can be tuned to manufacture functional 3D macro-, micro-, or nano-scale objects with nano-size features. Both the manufacturing technology and the specific structures considered in this proposal may potentially impact a wide variety of technological areas. For example 3D structures responsive to different external stimuli can be used as sensors, actuators, switches, vesicles for delivery and filtrating applications, etc. Integration of research, teaching, and outreach programs across multiple disciplines including polymer science, nanotechnology, and manufacturing will impact the education and training of a diverse student body at graduate, undergraduate, and high-school levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to investigate the manufacturing process and properties of elastomer-nanoporous metal bilayers. Nanoporous (NP) metals are characterized by very high surface-to-volume ratios are electrically conductive and have moderate stiffness. In this work, manufacturing of elastomer-NP metal bilayers was examined from a bottom up approach and fabrication of compliant, and functional foldable three dimensional heterostructures was examined after the bilayers were released from a constrained substrate. During the release, the flat bilayer changed shape depending on the mismatch strains that develop in the bilayers. The work quantified mismatch strains during curing of the elastomer, and during sputter deposition and subsequent etching of an alloy to form NP metal.

One of the major findings of the work involved discovery of a new mode of failure for elastomer and metallic film bilayers. The metal films were deposited under compressive strain with strong adhesion and developed wrinkles, as expected. They also formed through thickness cracks that pierced through the film and elastomer contrary to any theoretical predictions.  A model was developed to understand formation of the through thickness cracks in wrinkled films and it is proposed that they form from the top of the wrinkles in films that are very easy to fracture.  With this finding, phase diagrams predicting possible shapes in compliant bilayers need to be modified. The work has impact on the fabrication of flexible electronics using conductive metal as a component of the circuit. The program supported MS and PhD students in their studies as well as outreach programs through the Women in Engineering TEC camp for middle school girls.

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2018
Modified by: Antonia Antoniou
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this research was to investigate the manufacturing process and properties of elastomer-nanoporous metal bilayers. Nanoporous (NP) metals are characterized by very high surface-to-volume ratios are electrically conductive and have moderate stiffness. In this work, manufacturing of elastomer-NP metal bilayers was examined from a bottom up approach and fabrication of compliant, and functional foldable three dimensional heterostructures was examined after the bilayers were released from a constrained substrate. During the release, the flat bilayer changed shape depending on the mismatch strains that develop in the bilayers. The work quantified mismatch strains during curing of the elastomer, and during sputter deposition and subsequent etching of an alloy to form NP metal. One of the major findings of the work involved discovery of a new mode of failure for elastomer and metallic film bilayers. The metal films were deposited under compressive strain with strong adhesion and developed wrinkles, as expected. They also formed through thickness cracks that pierced through the film and elastomer contrary to any theoretical predictions. A model was developed to understand formation of the through thickness cracks in wrinkled films and it is proposed that they form from the top of the wrinkles in films that are very easy to fracture. With this finding, phase diagrams predicting possible shapes in compliant bilayers need to be modified. The work has impact on the fabrication of flexible electronics using conductive metal as a component of the circuit. The program supported MS and PhD students in their studies as well as outreach programs through the Women in Engineering TEC camp for middle school girls.
